# Marcella Hazan’s Bolognese Sauce Recipe - NYT Cooking (cooking.nytimes.com)

<https://cooking.nytimes.com/recipes/1015181-marcella-hazans-bolognese-sauce>

## Description

After the death in 2013 of Marcella Hazan, the cookbook author who changed the way Americans cook Italian food, The Times asked readers which of her recipes had become staples in their kitchens Many people answered with one word: “Bolognese.” Ms Hazan had a few recipes for the classic sauce, and they are all outstanding

# Marcella Hazan's Bolognese Sauce {#marcella-hazans-bolognese-sauce .pantry--title-display}

## Recipe from [Marcella Hazan](/search?q=Marcella+Hazan&action=click&module=byline&region=recipe%20page) {#recipe-from-marcella-hazan .pantry--ui-strong .byline_bylinePart__ysgt2}

## Adapted by [The New York Times](/search?q=The+New+York+Times&action=click&module=byline&region=recipe%20page) {#adapted-by-the-new-york-times .pantry--ui-strong .byline_bylinePart__ysgt2}

<figure class="recipeheaderimage_recipeHeaderImage__dFEBk">
<img src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/08/27/dining/ElCerrito_ThePasta2/ElCerrito_ThePasta2-articleLarge.jpg?w=1280&amp;q=75" style="position:absolute;height:100%;width:100%;left:0;top:0;right:0;bottom:0;object-fit:cover;color:transparent" data-fetchpriority="high" decoding="async" data-nimg="fill" sizes="100vw" srcset="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/08/27/dining/ElCerrito_ThePasta2/ElCerrito_ThePasta2-articleLarge.jpg?w=320&amp;q=75 320w, https://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/08/27/dining/ElCerrito_ThePasta2/ElCerrito_ThePasta2-articleLarge.jpg?w=384&amp;q=75 384w, https://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/08/27/dining/ElCerrito_ThePasta2/ElCerrito_ThePasta2-articleLarge.jpg?w=480&amp;q=75 480w, https://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/08/27/dining/ElCerrito_ThePasta2/ElCerrito_ThePasta2-articleLarge.jpg?w=768&amp;q=75 768w, https://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/08/27/dining/ElCerrito_ThePasta2/ElCerrito_ThePasta2-articleLarge.jpg?w=1024&amp;q=75 1024w, https://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/08/27/dining/ElCerrito_ThePasta2/ElCerrito_ThePasta2-articleLarge.jpg?w=1280&amp;q=75 1280w" alt="Marcella Hazan’s Bolognese Sauce" />

Time
:   At least 4 hours

Rating
:   5![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,){.stats_star__C0kZ2 .stats_filledStar__M479z}![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,){.stats_star__C0kZ2 .stats_filledStar__M479z}![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,){.stats_star__C0kZ2 .stats_filledStar__M479z}![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,){.stats_star__C0kZ2 .stats_filledStar__M479z}![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,){.stats_star__C0kZ2 .stats_filledStar__M479z}(19,020)

Notes
:   [Read community notes![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,){.stats_jumpToIcon__R22kc}](#notes_section){.link_link__7WCQy .link_default__lKxiG .stats_jumpToLink__TM_r4}

After the death in 2013 of Marcella Hazan, the cookbook author who changed the way Americans cook Italian food, The Times asked readers which of her recipes had become staples in their kitchens. Many people answered with one word: "Bolognese." Ms. Hazan had a few recipes for the classic sauce, and they are all outstanding. This one appeared in her book "Essentials of Classic Italian Cooking," and one reader called it "the gold standard." Try it and see for yourself. ---The New York Times

Featured in: [Tell Us Your Favorite Marcella Hazan Recipe](https://www.nytimes.com/2013/10/01/dining/tell-us-your-favorite-marcella-hazan-recipe.html){.link_link__7WCQy .link_default__lKxiG .topnote_articleLink__2kF0V}

## Ingredients {#ingredients .pantry--title-section-alternate .ingredients_heading__RdSek}

Yield:2 heaping cups, for about 6 servings and 1½ pounds pasta

-   1tablespoon vegetable oil
-   3tablespoons butter plus 1 tablespoon for tossing the pasta
-   ½cup chopped onion
-   ⅔cup chopped celery
-   ⅔cup chopped carrot
-   ¾pound ground beef chuck (or you can use 1 part pork to 2 parts beef)
-   Salt
-   Black pepper, ground fresh from the mill
-   1cup whole milk
-   Whole nutmeg
-   1cup dry white wine
-   1½cups canned imported Italian plum tomatoes, cut up, with their juice
-   1¼ to 1½pounds pasta
-   Freshly grated parmigiano-reggiano cheese at the table

Add to Your Grocery List

[Ingredient Substitution Guide](/guides/79-substitutions-for-cooking){.link_link__7WCQy .link_subdued__r23M2 .ingredients_linkAppearance___8Rdx}

## Preparation {#preparation .pantry--title-section-alternate .preparation_title___NSSd}

1.  Step 1

    Put the oil, butter and chopped onion in the pot and turn the heat on to medium. Cook and stir the onion until it has become translucent, then add the chopped celery and carrot. Cook for about 2 minutes, stirring vegetables to coat them well.

2.  Step 2

    Add ground beef, a large pinch of salt and a few grindings of pepper. Crumble the meat with a fork, stir well and cook until the beef has lost its raw, red color.

3.  Step 3

    Add milk and let it simmer gently, stirring frequently, until it has bubbled away completely. Add a tiny grating \-- about ⅛ teaspoon \-- of nutmeg, and stir.

4.  Step 4

    Add the wine, let it simmer until it has evaporated, then add the tomatoes and stir thoroughly to coat all ingredients well. When the tomatoes begin to bubble, turn the heat down so that the sauce cooks at the laziest of simmers, with just an intermittent bubble breaking through to the surface. Cook, uncovered, for 3 hours or more, stirring from time to time. While the sauce is cooking, you are likely to find that it begins to dry out and the fat separates from the meat. To keep it from sticking, add ½ cup of water whenever necessary. At the end, however, no water at all must be left and the fat must separate from the sauce. Taste and correct for salt.

5.  Step 5

    Toss with cooked drained pasta, adding the tablespoon of butter, and serve with freshly grated Parmesan on the side.

### About Us {#about-us .pantry--ui-strong .footer_subHeading__QxkiK}

NYT Cooking is a subscription service of The New York Times. It is a digital cookbook and cooking guide alike, available on all platforms, that helps home cooks of every level discover, save and organize the world's best recipes, while also helping them become better, more competent cooks. Subscribe now for full access.
